markdownRemark.html:
Question

Without explicitly calculating, find out which is bigger: eπe^\pieπ or πe\pi^eπe?

Hint

One method would be to expand exe^xex, another would be to observe the derivative of a special function

Answer

eπe^\pieπ

Solution

Initial Misstep

eπ≈23.14;πe≈22.46e^\pi \approx 23.14; \pi^e \approx 22.46eπ≈23.14;πe≈22.46, hence eπe^\pieπ is bigger. But this is not a valid method. We need to compare the two numbers without calculating them.

Method 1

Since ex=1+x+x22!+…e^x = 1 + x + \dfrac{x^2}{2!} + \ldotsex=1+x+2!x2​+…, we have ex>1+xe^x > 1+xex>1+x.

Let x=(πe−1)x = (\dfrac{\pi}{e} -1)x=(eπ​−1) and solve:

  ⟹  eπ/e−1>1+πe−1\implies e^{\pi/e - 1} > 1 + \dfrac{\pi}{e} - 1⟹eπ/e−1>1+eπ​−1

  ⟹  eπ/ee>πe\implies \dfrac{e^{\pi/e}}{e} > \dfrac{\pi}{e}⟹eeπ/e​>eπ​

  ⟹  eπ/e\implies e^{\pi/e}⟹eπ/e > π\piπ

  ⟹  eπ\implies e^\pi⟹eπ > πe\pi^eπe (raised to power eee on both sides)

Hence eπe^\pieπ is bigger.

Method 2

Suppose ∼\sim∼ denotes the relation between the two terms.

eπ∼πe  ⟺  e1/e∼π1/πe^\pi \sim \pi ^ e \iff e^{1/e} \sim \pi^{1/\pi}eπ∼πe⟺e1/e∼π1/π (raised to power 1/eπ1/{e\pi}1/eπ on both sides)

Note the function f(x)=x1/xf(x) = x^{1/x}f(x)=x1/x

To investigate how this function behaves, we need to take its derivative. But that's difficult.

Consider g(x)=ln⁡(f(x))=ln⁡(x)xg(x) = \ln(f(x)) = \dfrac{\ln(x)}{x}g(x)=ln(f(x))=xln(x)​

Differentiate using product rule:

(u⋅v)′=u′⋅v+u⋅v′(u \cdot v)' = u' \cdot v + u \cdot v'(u⋅v)′=u′⋅v+u⋅v′

where u=ln⁡(x),v=1/x,u′=1/x,v′=−1/x2u=\ln(x), v = 1/x, u'=1/x, v' = -1/x^2u=ln(x),v=1/x,u′=1/x,v′=−1/x2

g′(x)=1x⋅1x+ln⁡(x)⋅−1x2g'(x) = \dfrac{1}{x} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x} + \ln(x) \cdot \dfrac{-1}{x^2}g′(x)=x1​⋅x1​+ln(x)⋅x2−1​

g′(x)=1−ln⁡(x)x2g'(x) = \dfrac{1-\ln{(x)}}{x^2}g′(x)=x21−ln(x)​

The derivative g′g'g′ is negative if ln⁡(x)>1\ln(x) > 1ln(x)>1

  ⟹  g\implies g⟹g is decreasing for x>ex > ex>e

  ⟹  f\implies f⟹f is decreasing for x>ex > ex>e because ln⁡\lnln is a monotonic transformation.

  ⟹  f(e)>f(π)\implies f(e) > f(\pi)⟹f(e)>f(π) because e<πe<\pie<π

  ⟹  e1/e>π1/π\implies e^{1/e} > \pi^{1/\pi}⟹e1/e>π1/π

  ⟹  eπ>πe\implies e^\pi > \pi^e⟹eπ>πe

Thus eπe^\pieπ is bigger.

Notes:

  1. This puzzle is usually considered easy because it is easy to ask and verify (using a calculator). But when solving, it is a more difficult than many of the hard puzzles here.

  2. Here's a plot of f(x)=x1/xf(x)=x^{1/x}f(x)=x1/x

  3. This is a common question in placement tests. It would be a good idea to memorize that f(x)=x1/xf(x) = x^{1/x}f(x)=x1/x is decreasing in the range x>ex > ex>e. Using this, we can prove other variants.

    relation    using function
    eπe^{\pi}eπ >>> πe\pi^{e}πe f(x)f(x)f(x) at x=e,πx=e, \pix=e,π
    e2πe^{2 \pi}e2π >>> π2e\pi ^ {2e}π2e f2(x)f^2(x)f2(x) at x=e,πx=e, \pix=e,π
    eπ2e^{\pi^2}eπ2 >>> πe2\pi ^ {e^2}πe2 f(x)\sqrt{f(x)}f(x)​ at x=e2,π2x=e^2, \pi^2x=e2,π2
    eπe^{\sqrt{\pi}}eπ​ <<< πe\pi ^ {\sqrt{e}}πe​ f(x)2f(x)^2f(x)2 at x=e,πx=\sqrt{e}, \sqrt{\pi}x=e​,π​
